title: Power Query Basics
videoScript: Welcome to Excel Lesson 14: Power Query Basics. In this video we will focus on practical, job-style usage of these features.
blogArticle:
## Power Query Basics

Import, clean, merge and append repeating monthly files.

In this lesson, we will work on a realistic, job-style Excel sheet. The goal is not only to learn the function names,
but to understand **when** to use them and **how** they appear in actual office work.

At the end of the lesson, you should be able to:
- Explain the concept in simple words.
- Apply it on a small sample data table.
- Modify someone else's sheet safely without breaking formulas.
practiceProblems: Open a blank sheet and recreate the sample shown in the video for Power Query Basics.
Change a few values and confirm that all formulas update correctly.
Explain in your own words where this feature would be used in a real office scenario.
homework: Build a small table using your own sample data.
Add formulas/functions discussed in this lesson.
Save the file as Lesson-14-practice.xlsx and upload to Google Classroom.

quiz.question: In everyday work, why would you use the main concept from 'Power Query Basics'?
options: Only to make the file look fancy
To automate repetitive calculations and reduce manual errors
It is rarely used in real jobs
quiz.explanation: Real office work loves automation and consistency. The features from this lesson help avoid manual, error-prone work.

jobAssignments.title: Power Query – Monthly Report Automation
jobAssignments.brief: Use Power Query to import, clean and append monthly CSV files into a single clean table.
tasks: Connect to all provided monthly CSV files from a folder.
Promote headers, remove unnecessary columns and fix data types.
Append all months into one query and load to an Excel table.
Create a Pivot Table report from the clean output table.
hints: Use the 'From Folder' connector in Power Query.
Apply transformations once and then reuse them when new CSVs arrive.
jobAssignments.hiddenSolution: Use Data > Get Data > From Folder, combine the files, clean columns, set data types, and load to a sheet named Clean_Data. Then build a Pivot for summary. Refreshing will update for new months with no formula changes.

interviewQA.question: What is a Pivot Table and when would you use it in real work?
interviewQA.hint: Think about summarising large raw tables.
interviewQA.answer: A Pivot Table summarises a large table without changing the source data. You can drag fields to rows, columns and values to analyse sales, headcount, etc. It is ideal when management asks for summaries such as sales by region/month or employees by department.

interviewQA.question: How do you ensure that a dashboard or report stays correct when the data grows over time?
interviewQA.hint: Tables, named ranges, and structured references.
interviewQA.answer: Base all formulas, charts, and Pivot Tables on Excel Tables or named ranges instead of fixed A1:C10 style ranges. Then, adding rows at the bottom automatically updates the report after refresh.
